node.content:
On many campuses, WordPress isn’t the only CMS in use. And if we start thinking about learning management systems, campus portals, and the many other ways our schools use the web, WordPress is clearly just one part of a complex web landscape.

This episode features WPCampus community members Brian DeConinck and Eric Sembrat. Eric is a developer and web manager with Georgia Tech’s College of Engineering. He recently spoke at HighEdWeb on the topic: “Unbundle Your Institution: Building a Web CMS Ecosystem.”

  • View Eric’s slides from HighEdWeb 2017
  • Find Eric online: webbeh.com

As mentioned in the episode, the WPCampus Online Call for Speakers ends on November 10, 2017.

NOTE: Between when this episode was recorded and published, the deadline for applying to host WPCampus 2018 was extended! Submit your application by Friday, November 3!

node.content:
When we talk about WordPress in higher ed, we often talk about technology—themes and plugins, server configurations, etc. But at some point, the developers have to let go and the content creators take over. In higher ed, that brings with it a whole new set of challenges.

This episode features WPCampus members Brian DeConinck, Jen McFarland, and Shelley Keith. Shelley is the Director of Digital Communications at University of Mary Washington, and she presented at the 2016 WPCampus conference on the topic: “We Don’t Need No Education: Web Governance Through On-Demand Online Training.”

The slides from Shelley’s presentation and the training materials she has produced for UMW are available for public viewing and reuse at your institution. For more discussion around web governance, you can join Shelley’s Facebook group.
